awd_titl_txt: Waves, Bubbles and Splashes from Jovian Impacts
awd_abstract_narration: The proposing team is developing a linked series of 3-dimensional hydrodynamic models for the impact, plume blowout, and plume flight/splash phases of the Shoemaker-Levy 9 (SL9) and 2009 Jupiter impact events. With previous NSF support, they have focused on impact and plume development modeling. In this project, they will model the plume blowout and waves generated in the Jovian atmosphere. The models will test theories for the expanding rings seen by the Hubble Space Telescope (HST). Each theory is sensitive to different fundamental Jovian atmospheric parameters; successful match of a mechanism to data will yield one or more parameter measurements. The composite model will distinguish among the competing theories by replicating each one's essential physics and determining whether it is consistent with the impact energy and HST images. The proposers will adjust the viscosity in the splash model until the outer part of the plume re-entry shock matches the expanding infrared rings; this will place a tight constraint on Jovian eddy viscosity. The project will test the hypothesis that the plumes had a strong density enhancement at their maximum velocity that produced the observed infrared ring and infrared light curves. The work will produce the first observationally-constrained 3D radiative-hydrodynamic-chemical model of all phases of a cometary impact. The project will, in addition, support the work and training of one graduate student, and the proposing team will produce video animations from their simulations that will be useful for public outreach.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: One of our major objectives was to study how certain impact parameters effect the immediate aftermath (e.g., the plume development stage) of an impact event. By studying the the 2009 impact and comparing it to the Shoemaker-Levy 9 (SL9) events we investigated the effect of changing the impact angle and we found that shallow impacts created considerably smaller plumes heights not only because the material was ejected at a lower angle but also because the ejection speeds were much slower compared to otherwise idential higher-angle impactors.  The cases were later expanded to a larger set of angles while using SL9 and 2009 as constraints and our results matched all observables parameters. We also studied the 2010 and 2012 impact events to investigate the impact properties of smaller sized objects. The energy deposition curves from our simulations were in good agreement with the observed light curves. Another major goal of the project was to study the later phases of impacts and determine the correlation (if any) between visible characteristics in the aftermath of an event (e.g., the rings and cresents for SL9 impacts) and the impact parameters. To achieve this goal, we had to develop a software tool that enabled us to extend the grid, which in turn permits long term, extended spatial scale simulations. Those cases were not fully completed at the conclusion of this project and they will form the basis of our subsequent work.

Our work has produced 7 conference abstracts at major international meetings, 2 papers with the submission of one additional paper imminent and we have data for one more paper.  

Broader Impact: Throughout the project at the University of Central Florida (UCF) and Florida Tech, 2 graduate students and 15 undergrads worked on the project in one form or another. The research they carried out was part of one dissertation, 4 undergrad showcase presentations, 3 senior projects, and due to the experience these students gained, 4 of them received internship offers and another 4 got graduate fellowships (3 of the students haven’t graduated yet at the time this report is being written). Last but not least, partially due to the effort he made on this project, the PI was hired into a faculty position.

Results from our work has been also disseminated to the public. Our results appeared in two science public lectures (two of Florida Tech’s most viewed Science Public lectures ever), 5 department colloquiums, 4 freshman seminars, 2 journal club presentations, 2 press reports, and in a dedicated episode of NBC’s “Science Behind the News” series (available on NBC’s website, on YouTube and in the Science360 app). Our results became part of the course material in UCF’s AST6908 “Planetary Atmospheres 2” and Florida Tech’s SPS1020 “Introduction to Space Sciences”, SPS4035 “Comparative Planetology” and SPS4030 “Physics of the Atmosphere” courses


Last Modified: 11/29/2018
Modified by: Csaba Palotai
